WRITING.TITLE: Who was that guy? (Furiosa's second-in-command)
WRITING.TEXT: I've been reading through the Mad Max wiki, and I've noticed that there seems to be no information about Furiosa's apparent second-in-command (the guy who hangs off the door of the war rig at the start of her escape). Nothing on Google, either, and I can't even see a credit for him on IMDb (I'm guessing his name was "Gru" or something similar, judging by what Nux shouted when he tried to shoot Furiosa). Any ideas if this character even had a name, and what his story might have been? Surely I can't be the only one to have been fascinated by him!

One thing that really drove this home for me was when I went to see it for the second time. While I don't have epilepsy, strobes and flashes still make me uncomfortable due to sensory issues, so I had my eyes shut for a lot of the storm sequence the first time around. When it had ended, I was a little lost over what was going on for a short while. The second time I saw this film I decided to try and watch all of that scene, and found that I'd missed quite a huge chunk of the story simply by not looking for that minute or so, despite the fact that I could still hear everything. (And I agree with the others here; the visual storytelling and refusal to rely on dialogue and exposition makes this film even more fantastic.)

I've seen it twice so far, and I'm going again tomorrow with my dad (he's in dire need of a proper break from his work and it's been forever since we last went to see a film together, so I figured a cinema trip was in order). I've only seen it in 2D, so I'm hoping he'll agree to a 3D showing!

If you have a Comixology account, it's also available as a digital comic there. It might be the easiest way to get it if you can't get hold of the print copy in time and have a device to read it on (I think they work well enough on computers too, for that matter...).
Snitter? A Plague Dogs reference, by any chance?
Congratulations! (I can't think of any quotes for this that haven't already been used... will "Oh what a lovely day!" do? :P)

That one vehicle being lifted into the air during the storm and exploding in a ball of flames. The look on Nux's face was pretty much exactly how I must have looked the first time I saw it! (Also, the shot of the taiko drummers on the back of the Doof Wagon, and the way the camera swings around right as the music builds to a crescendo to reveal the Coma Doof Warrior for the first time.)
Right, now I kind of want to design a War Boy named either Rowf or Tod. We may as well get the full cast here! :P

Did they use the same sound effect from that scene? I've not yet seen 127 Hours (because I'm a wuss, admittedly) but I'm sure I heard a sound effect while Deadpool was hacking off his hand that sounded pretty much as I imagine the "nerve-cutting" sound effect from the original film to sound.

WRITING.TITLE: Does anyone else remember an old video called "Youtubers"?
WRITING.TEXT: I've been looking for a video I saw years ago that popped up on Youtube (close to the early days of the site) simply called "Youtubers" and featuring a compilation of early Youtube celebrities and vlogs. I seem to remember it being around 11 minutes long with some melancholy piano music in the background, and I remember it featuring clips of lonelygirl15 and geriatric1927 in particular. It was quite popular at the time, and I clearly remember it being featured on a few news sites. Does anyone else remember it?

WRITING.TITLE: Geek Squad UK repair cost?
WRITING.TEXT: I dropped my phone yesterday and cracked the screen, and I'm planning on taking it to be repaired tomorrow. I was going to take it back to Carphone Warehouse, where I originally got it, and apparently their repairs are covered by Geek Squad, who charge anything from #163;60 to #163;200 depending on the Samsung model. Has anyone else here taken their S7 to them to have the screen replaced, and if so, could you please let me know roughly how much it cost? It'd be good to know in advance whether to go straight to them or find somewhere a bit more affordable first (or at least have an opportunity to brace myself for the huge chunk in my bank account after this!)
It's got a wonderful defence mechanism. You don't dare kill it.

Update: After months of further searching and at 3 in the morning UK time, I've finally found the video again! It turns out it was made back in 2006, and so the snapshot you get of Youtube through this is very different to what it is today - less of a huge media platform filled with online celebrities and production companies and more of a tight-knit community. Here's the video for anyone who's curious! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5M5qk1E-4z4

WRITING.TITLE: Everyone surprise this guy by jumping into his PUBG stream! He deserves views!
Looking for orchestral copyright-free music
WRITING.TEXT: I've been looking for copyright-free music for my streams (I've been mostly playing soundtracks to movies and games, but of course they still get flagged and muted as VODs) but the only Twitchfm music I can find is almost entirely techno, which doesn't really fit my art streams, plus I'm just not that into it. I'd love to find something orchestral to draw along to, but aside from old classical music there seems to be nothing out there - in particular, anything that sounds like it belongs in a movie or could have been released by Two Steps From Hell would be ideal. Any advice would be greatly appreciated!

I was thinking about this the other day, oddly. I'm a moderator in a few channels as well as a streamer, and while I enjoy streaming I feel even more passionate about modding. I've come to the conclusion that it's the same reason I used to be a stage hand for an amateur dramatic company - I love working behind the scenes to support creativity, and there's something very satisfying about knowing that I'm able to keep negativity and trolls out of chat, offer the streamer a helping hand when they need it and generally help things run smoothly. As for those who seem to beg to be a mod the moment they come into a chat, I agree that it's probably for the status, but wanting to be a moderator when you know the responsibilities is all about being able to help and knowing that you're supporting someone's creativity, at least in my case.

WRITING.TITLE: Question about wearing glasses with the Vive
WRITING.TEXT: I've found several posts about similar topics, but they all seem to cover wearing the headset without glasses, or with inserts, so I was wondering if anyone could help me figure out whether I could successfully wear glasses with a Vive. I've been saving up to buy one, but I'm shortsighted with astigmatism (20/200 vision without glasses) and need my glasses to see, and I can't wear contact lenses. I have a Samsung Gear VR that fits around my glasses just fine, so with that in mind, would I be able to wear glasses in the Vive without issues? (Updated with a little more detail now that I've been able to dig out the results of my last eye test!)

I'm thinking of buying this skirt from Joe Brown's for a family party, but I'm utterly new to fashion (my idea of being stylish has always been wearing a t-shirt other than black with my jeans) and I have no idea what it'd look good with. As it's online with no shops near me that sell Joe Brown's, I can't try it on in person with anything, either. Does anyone have any suggestions for what I could wear? Anything with sleeves and without an exposed back would be a good start (scars and generally bad skin on my back that I'd prefer to keep covered, plus in this weather I'd rather not wear a cami top) and too much red isn't a great idea thanks to my rosacea, but besides that I'm open to suggestions. I'm thinking of wearing the skirt with some black tights and ankle boots (the "Cute to Boot" ones from the same site) if that helps - I'm hoping for a nice autumnal look if possible. Any help would be greatly appreciated! [https://www.joebrowns.co.uk/sp+women-womens-skirts-charismatic-cord-mini-skirt+ws094?contenta=CrossSale4](https://www.joebrowns.co.uk/sp+women-womens-skirts-charismatic-cord-mini-skirt+ws094?contenta=CrossSale4)

So glad I'm not alone in this! I'm writing this at just after 4 in the morning after going to bed with the worst trapped air in my chest that I've had in ages - I felt ridiculously sick, my chest hurt, I couldn't stop shivering and it was generally a miserable time (on my birthday of all days, too) It's since worked its way down in my sleep to cause an IBS flare-up which woke me up. Currently waiting for that to settle and wishing someone would do some research into treatment for this already! I've had it all my life, and yes, it's been this bad before...

I've never been able to swallow pills either! I have to chew even the smallest bits of food before I can swallow them - not sure if it's related to the lack of burping, but if it is that'd be interesting!
If this turns out to be a new subset of dysfunction of the belch reflex, I'm calling it DBR - "No Escape From Headaches" variant #128539;
I'm never that brave! I just have to take them as dispersible tablets or suspensions - thankfully I've resigned myself to the awful tastes by now!

WRITING.TITLE: Problems mounting my horse
WRITING.TEXT: I keep having an issue where I can't mount my horse if it's carrying anything (ie. a deer or a hogtied captive). So far it's happening consistently, and it's making progressing a nightmare, as the only way I can get my horse anywhere in those situations is to lead it. Is this a bug, or is there something I'm missing?
Ah. Yeah... that was it, thanks! (I'm blaming a mix of muscle memory and a head cold for this!)
I think the problem was that in my sickness-addled state, I was pressing square... #128580; Thankfully fixed now!
I'm in the UK :) Any injections will have to wait until I've dealt with my needle phobia (currently going through therapy for that) but I've read a bit about Botox treatment for it.
I've been getting twinges at the base of my skull that definitely seem connected to trapped air, if that's anything!
Just had this happen to me with the silver Turkoman! I'm kind of disappointed, I was looking forward to keeping him!

WRITING.TITLE: Terrified of nail infection
WRITING.TEXT: Yesterday I accidentally stabbed myself under the nail with the tip of another nail - having dyspraxia, I'm prone to this kind of thing. It hurt then, and it's been a bit sore since, and now I've noticed that it looks redder in that one spot that the rest of the nail, and it feels warm. Of course, now I'm terrified about things like sepsis. I've just put some Savlon on the area, but I can't stop shaking and panicking. I guess I'm just looking for reassurance that others have been through this, and that it isn't as dire as I'm imagining it.
Yep, usually in my throat/upper chest! Back when I was in school, I was also fairly convinced that it somehow timed itself to only ever go off during the quietest moments and exams. :P

WRITING.TITLE: Which voice type does the role of Hades from "Hadestown" fall under?
WRITING.TEXT: I know next to nothing about music theory and actually identifying voice types, but I'm curious about the role of Hades in "Hadestown", being pretty much the lowest sung role I've heard so far. Would the role's range fall under baritone, bass or even basso profundo? EDIT: For some reason the link I'd intended to post didn't work, but an example song is "Hey Little Songbird".

Yeah, for some reason it didn't seem to want to work. I've mentioned the example song title in the updated post ("Hey Little Songbird") while I try to figure out why the link didn't work correctly. :)

Update - it seems to have completely settled on its own, which is good. :) It was a bit sore still the day after but nowhere near as red, and today I had to take a moment to remind myself which thumb it was. And I feel rather silly for building it up into something massive (even though yes, that's my health anxiety in a nutshell)

I adore gaming, but my dyspraxia certainly makes it difficult! I have terrible aim, I can't steer particularly well, my reaction times aren't the best and my poor control of my hands makes it both difficult to perform QTEs and highly likely that I'll accidentally twitch my thumbs against buttons and end up being the cause of friendly fire. I don't play online for that reason, and accessibility options for QTEs have been lifesavers for me. :)

If you do decide to give it a go, one thing I recommend NOT doing is buying a cheap bundle of unbranded threads, thinking that's a good substitute. It is, right until you lose one of the threads and realise that without a proper brand and colour number, you can't replace it. Stick with the brand that the pattern mentions and you'll be fine. :) (And definitely give it a go! Cross stitch is addictively fun! :D)

My cat loves investigating via sniffing. Whenever I get a parcel or buy anything new, the first thing I'll do with it is go "You wanna sniff?" to my cat. Without fail, he takes me up on it and has a good long sniff of whatever I've got to investigate.
Adorable cats and Blade Runner references. My day is made!

WRITING.TITLE: [CHAT] Tips needed for starting threads (AKA. to loop start or not to loop start?)
WRITING.TEXT: I've been reading a lot about starting threads using loop starts lately (as in doubling a single thread and looping the needle to anchor your first stitch) but the one time I've tried it, I ended up wasting a lot more thread than I usually do thanks to the amount left unusable once I'd finished the section and cut the thread. Does anyone have any suggestions, or any alternative start methods? I don't knot my thread, and instead I tend to anchor my first stitches with a double cross stitch on the first square, but I'm not sure how wise that is either!

This is one of those photos that I adore, while at the same time it creeps me out for reasons I can't fully explain. I think it's partly how utterly alien the pillars are, and how incomprehensibly massive.
Well, there go my plans for sleeping tonight!

Whispering in dialogue. It's such an uncommon and impractical thing in actual speech unless you're sneaking around or trying not to disturb someone, but film characters seem to use it in every third sentence, and it never fails to look ridiculous (case in point, one scene in the show "Vikings" that featured two characters stood quite far apart and having a conversation on a windy hill. One of them was whispering and somehow miraculously being heard by the other character. It was hilariously stupid.)

If you're out in a field and you need to climb over/otherwise touch a wire fence, always test it with the back of your hand, never the palm. If it's electrified, it'll cause the muscles in your hand to involuntarily clench, meaning that if you touch it with your palm you'll automatically grab hold and you won't be able to let go.

WRITING.TITLE: [CHAT] Question about the official Pusheen kit
WRITING.TEXT: I finally got the Pusheen kit today! It looks adorable, and I can't wait to get started, but I'm a bit sceptical about the booklet advising single strands for the patterns. Has anyone tried with double stands, or does it look fine with single strands?
It doesn't say - I think I've read somewhere online that it's 12 count? It's a very low count either way, 12 or 14 at a guess.

WRITING.TITLE: [FO] Finished my first piece from the mini Pusheen kit!

WRITING.TEXT: Hadestown is pretty incredible, but I'd recommend waiting a couple of months until they release the full Broadway soundtrack, or at least treat the current theatre workshop live album (which leaves out a good chunk of songs) as a taster. Definitely worth checking out, though!
I do! I've never really liked English breakfast (I have mine without milk or sugar, and a lot of the main brands taste too bitter without either) so Earl Grey is my go-to tea. :)
That's beautiful! :D Once I finish my current project, this may have to be next!

WRITING.TITLE: Sketch of Hades I drew a couple of months ago!

WRITING.TEXT: That's gorgeous! And I know the pain of pet hair in projects all too well. I've started keeping a pair of tweezers near me while I'm stitching to pull my black cat's stray hairs out of my projects!
"Dentist" from Little Shop of Horrors could be a good option?

WRITING.TITLE: Advice needed from emote artists
WRITING.TEXT: I'm designing a set of emotes, and I need some advice on lettering for the "hype" and "lurk" emotes. My hand-lettering skills aren't the best, so I was going to try a font instead, but nothing seems to work. Can anyone suggest any good fonts they've used in the past for emotes?

WRITING.TITLE: A warmup sketch I did of Shuga Cain!

WRITING.TEXT: This was the reference I used btw! https://vignette.wikia.nocookie.net/logosrupaulsdragrace/images/2/23/ShugaCain2.jpg/revision/latest/zoom-crop/width/320/height/320?cb=20190223180626
It took far too long for me to realise it wasn't real! I got so excited about getting to see Ongina live for a moment!

WRITING.TITLE: I wanted to practice quick sketches of bodies in motion - the "Queens Everywhere" video turned out to be perfect!

WRITING.TEXT: A'keria had both the best and hardest poses to draw. Those tassels made it so hard to see what she was doing! XD
Heh, thanks! XD
Yes! Do it! :D
Thank you :D I was actually really determined to get that one in there - it took a lot of rewinding to time that pause just right, but I just had to get that shoulder move sketched out!
Go for it! We need more art in the world! :)
Oh, I paused the video each time. I'm not that brave yet. XD
Thank you! lt;3
I love that design, but I can never get the feet right (they're so fiddly!) This looks amazing!

WRITING.TITLE: Best part of a new character sheet: getting to draw all over "character appearance"! (His name is Skullrar AKA. Skully, the human barbarian gladiator)

WRITING.TEXT: Thank you! :D
Oh god, it does and now I can't unsee it. XD

The best two things I can suggest are life drawing, and taking note of what you particularly like about other character designs to help kick-start your own inspiration. Drawing daily is great, too! Practice is everything! :) (Seriously, compare your drawings at the start and end of a week, and you'll already see so much improvement) PS: If you don't have any life drawing classes near you, look up sites such as Line of Action and SketchDaily to let you do it for free online. Or if you want to practice drawing bodies in motion, one of my recent favourite exercises has been to find a music video with plenty of dancing, pause it at random intervals and roughly sketch the dancers mid-dance.
I do! Feel free to DM me if you'd like to discuss that further :) (And thank you!)
Anyone can draw! It's all about practice (I know, that's the biggest clich #233;, but it's true. Half of it is just building muscle memory.)
That's beautiful XD
Thank you! lt;3
Thanks! :D
Thank you! :D (Even better if that personality is "smarmy bastard who thinks he's the best in the world but is really a bit of a vain whiny baby")
Yeah, that also comes with practice. It's a pain getting used to doing, admittedly...
Oh, nice! This will be my first time using one, so I'm excited to see what it's like.

WRITING.TITLE: A never produced Chessex "matt gold plated" polyset I bought from TDSO's clearance section a few years ago :)
Some never produced Chessex metal plated gold matt dice I got in a TDSO clearance sale, and one of my favourite sets to use!

WRITING.TEXT: Yes! Thank you, I've been looking for more details since I bought them! The site I got them from listed them as "Chessex metal plated matt gold 7 dice polyset", but I could never find anything else listed under that name once I'd bought them. I always thought that they don't particularly feel like actual metal plating! (Gorgeous to use, though)
I think it's plate (or a material mimicking metal plate) over a plastic die. :) It's definitely one solid piece.
I have a set like this on the way! Seeing this makes me even more excited for it to arrive :D

WRITING.TITLE: Me: "Nah, I won't need more than a set or two." Also me:

WRITING.TEXT: They're Chessex Dark Grey and Copper opaque dice. :) I got them from a local comic shop, although I'd recommend checking them over for quality before buying them - when I got mine home, I realised that the d20 was chipped on one side. So I'm keeping the rest as backups, but the d20 was sadly weighted from that damage and is in the process of being turned into a necklace instead.
I mean... no comment. XD
Right? I just watched a panel video that explained that Wil Wheaton keeps barrels of them. Honestly, I think my subconscious self has already taken it as a challenge.

WRITING.TITLE: Not a hugely interesting thing, but I had my first go at re-inking a die today!

WRITING.TEXT: Those Q Workshop dragon dice were my first ever set! You've really done their look justice with this whole composition :)
Thanks :) I used a Uni Posca paint pen, with a tissue and miniature brush to neaten it up as much as I could.

Yeah, that does seem to be an unfortunate trend with Q Workshop... I use other dice now when I play (generally Chessex nowadays) but they'll always stay in my bag as a sort of set of mascots/lucky charms. :)

Good idea, I'll try that next time :) This was my first ever attempt, and a bit of a spur of the moment thing (I had that d20 sitting there in a drawer and the paint marker next to me) so next time I re-ink I'll see if I can get hold of some rubbing alcohol first.

WRITING.TITLE: When you have a damaged die that you love too much to throw away...

WRITING.TEXT: It was made by GeekyDice on Etsy, for anyone curious! The d20 in question arrived already damaged, and since I didn't take it out of its box for a while after buying it, it was already too late to return it, and I love the look of it too much to just get rid of it. So I sent it off to that seller to turn into a necklace instead!
You look so cool, and I'm so jealous! XD Brilliant job on the cosplay!
It's scratched and a bit chipped on the other side. It actually gives it a quite nice "battle damage" look. #128539;

WRITING.TITLE: Chessex Glitter Ruby AKA. All Of The Sparkles

WRITING.TEXT: The dice bag is from The Cognitive Merchant btw!
They have _ :)
Yeah, IMO Chessex are by far the easiest to read (good clear font, d4 numbers at the top, sideways percentile numbers to be as large as possible, etc.)
Aren't they? :D I was agonising over whether to get them for a while, but in the end I had to. They're completely unlike any other set I have, and I love their "Dorothy's ruby slippers" look so much!
Hadestown and Sweeney Todd are two of my absolute favourites, along with the short-lived Lord of the Rings musical, Come From Away, The Secret Garden and Miss Saigon not too far behind. :)

WRITING.TITLE: My first attempt at Jo Nakashima's "Simplified Eagle" (and my first attempt at using foil back paper!)
Help needed IDing this d12, please!

WRITING.TEXT: It's from Cymbeline Games, but I'm pretty sure TDSO source their own brand dice from HD Dice, which Cymbeline Games also stocks. So it could be another HD Dice set! (I'm pretty sure mine is too translucent to be that specific set, but the numbers look similar)
Thank you! lt;3

It's a challenge, but it's doable. If it helps, I find that complex models like this feel a lot more feasible if you take regular breaks, have a hot drink within reach and let yourself swear at the model as much as you like every time you get to a tricky bit. #128539;

WRITING.TITLE: Finally got my first Chessex Borealis set today!
I took advantage of the sunny weather to take a photo of some of my glittery dice at their sparkliest

WRITING.TEXT: That looks so sweet! :D Very neatly done, too! (I may have to treat myself to that kit soon...)

They're HD Iridescent Blue originally, although I imagine they've been given different names in other shops. The red dice are Chessex Glitter Ruby, and the deeper blue are Chessex Borealis Light Blue (new glitter, although I'd love to get hold of the old glitter dice someday). The pink amp; blue with the band of glitter are HD Bluestar Streak, and while I assume the white dice are HD, I'm not sure. TDSO lists them as Confetti Mist Star, though. :)

WRITING.TITLE: Took my HD Iridescent Blues out into the garden to take some especially glittery photos :)

WRITING.TEXT: Another autistic person here - I just wanted to add, it's great if you enjoy categorising and listing things too. I have a notebook full of tables and charts for everything in the game (plus dream farm plans) that I add to whenever I feel like it, and it's an amazingly satisfying thing to do. :) (Not something you have to do, by any means - it's just something I find very relaxing)

WRITING.TITLE: Pink, purple, blue amp; gold = my new favourite dice palette
I spent the heatwave drawing some of my favourite D amp;D monsters

WRITING.TEXT: Thank you! I'm sure it's becoming a clich #233; with how much it gets said, but regular practice really is the best way to improve #128515;
Well, I'm never unseeing that now XD
Aww, thank you! #10084; #65039;
Thanks! It's a demilich, whose name is now Pizza Skull because that's kind of perfect.
Oh, nice! I'd love to see the tattoo in this subreddit when it's done! :D

The three at the front are from Critical Kit #128515; Enchanted Gold, Blue Jelly and Snowglobe Cherry. The gold dice are Chessex Faux Metal Jacket, which I got from a TDSO clearance sale and occasionally pop up on eBay.

Sadly, that's the only set I haven't ID-ed yet... I've had people guess that they're WizKids Serpent dice, but the inking doesn't match, so I have no idea! (I got them in a clearance sale mystery bag, to make matters worse!)

Update - I think I've stumbled across them online! On the Beholder's Gaze site they're called Green Sheen (I'm 99% sure they're the same dice) https://www.beholdersgaze.com/collections/new-additions/products/green-sheen

WRITING.TITLE: When your barbarian keeps getting himself hurt...

WRITING.TEXT: When I was little, I had a cat who adored cucumber. We had to be careful to never leave any out of the fridge, or we'd come back to find her munching on it, or the very chewed up aftermath.

WRITING.TITLE: An ancient brass d6 on display at a Viking festival today
Looking for advice on taking up archery with a disability
WRITING.TEXT: I had my first go at archery today, at a "have a go" display at a Viking festival. I have dyspraxia (coordination and fine motor skill disorder, for anyone unaware) and I'm hypermobile, but the instructors there were great and very accommodating, and I had a lot of fun despite my difficulties with it. I'd love to take it further and sign up for classes, but I'm aware that given the difficulty I had using a bow, holding it up for that long and trying to aim, I'll probably need some further help, at least at first. Does anyone here have any tips for taking up archery with a disability like mine, and would many archery clubs be willing and able to take on newbies who have more difficulties with aiming and general movement than most?

WRITING.TITLE: A few of my translucent dice backlit

WRITING.TEXT: "You Won't Believe How Many Sides These Dice Have!"
That's HD Luminous Koi :)

Thank you so much to everyone who commented and gave advice/encouragement - I took the plunge and got in contact with my local archery club, and I've been invited to come over, check the place out and talk with the instructors about my disabilities and how they can best help me. And I've already picked out the model of bow I want as my first (a WNS Forged Elite Alpha) and set a tentative date for when I start lessons. #128515; Thank you so much, I'm still a bit nervous, but I feel much more reassured now.

WRITING.TITLE: Butterfly Bow dice from Critical Kit! (Originally Udixi's Dreamlike series "Pink Layer With Pink Butterfly Inside")

WRITING.TEXT: They really are #128515; This is actually a replacement set - the first set had a manufacturing flaw with the d6, so I got in contact with them, and less than a day later a replacement set arrived!

[5e] How essential is darkvision for player characters in Descent Into Avernus? I'll be playing the campaign in the next few weeks, and the character I had in mind is a Goliath barbarian to act as the party's tank/heavy hitter. Goliaths don't have darkvision, however, so I'm torn over whether to bring him into this campaign or save him for another.

WRITING.TITLE: Help needed IDing this Chessex d12 - do I have Speckled Water or Speckled Blueberry?

WRITING.TEXT: Ah, that makes sense. I think what confused me was the old mould used to make this (with dots rather than underscores on the 6 and 9) but then I have no idea when Water was first brought out. Good to know, anyway!
This looks amazing! :D I'd love to cosplay as Entrapta someday... (And your eye makeup looks gorgeous!)

I went to my first archery lesson at the weekend and I loved it, but I was seriously aching for the next couple of days, especially in my bow arm amp; shoulder. What exercises do you recommend to condition myself a bit more for holding up a bow for that long (keeping in mind that I have basically no exercise equipment other than a couple of small weights that I bought for this and no access to a gym) and how should I warm up amp; cool down before and after shooting to minimise pain?

According to Song Facts: (https://www.songfacts.com/facts/the-foundations/build-me-up-buttercup) "There was a scene in a Red Dwarf episode, that this song was played for a musical montage type flashback" Maybe something that was shown in whichever episode this was when it first aired, then was taken out later due to copyright? The same thing happened with Being Human (an Alabama 3 song played during a scene in the original broadcast, and was replaced with standard music on DVD) so it could be a case of the same thing happening here?

Could be played in a different part/episode of the show that others may have remembered it from? The assumption that it's really Tongue Tied seems to stem from that being the first song that people jump to when they think of Red Dwarf - if it's from a montage, it could maybe be from a different episode, or even something like a Smeg Ups compilation. Either way, I'm curious now and rather determined to find this for myself!

WRITING.TITLE: Autumn palette! (Featuring Chessex, HD and Udixi dice)

WRITING.TEXT: Those are Chessex Festive Sunburst :) (Not as swirly as some others, but they still look gorgeous without swirls IMO)
I think my dad may still have the original DVDs of series 8. I'll ask him tonight and see if I can borrow them to check if it's there :)
Always happy to ~~be a shameless enabler~~ help!
As someone whose all-time favourite D amp;D monster is the beholder, I approve!

WRITING.TITLE: My first ever mixed/mostly OG Chessex Borealis die!

WRITING.TEXT: How am I supposed to aim barebow? I'm two weeks into lessons, and in a square stance with the corner of my mouth as my anchor point, the arrow appears diagonal and I'm lucky if I can hit my target at all instead of the back wall (I shoot left-handed and have even tried shutting my right eye to make sure I'm aiming right, and I don't think it's any sort of fear of the string - I try to keep it pressed into my face as much as possible when aiming). I've tried moving my bow arm forwards a bit, drawing an imaginary line from the arrow to the target, etc. but still no luck. I feel like there must be a trick to this that I'm just not seeing.
As if we didn't need more proof of how bad this is, I honestly thought this was a photo of a horribly diseased iguana while I was scrolling!
That actually explains a lot... I had a hotdog with fried onions for lunch today. I've been suffering ever since!
Seconded. I'm a newbie too, and his videos have helped a lot with learning to shoot well (and helped dissipate a lot of my nerves about my first lesson). :)

I've tried repeatedly, but I cannot for the life of me seem to make full sense of Easton's arrow spine chart, at least to the point of figuring out what I can get for my first set of arrows besides expensive carbon (which I'd rather not get just yet, still being very new at this). So which spine rating would be best recommended for 26" Easton Jazz arrows, shot from a 20lb 66" recurve bow? (A Ragim Matrix Evo to be precise, which is the bow I'm hoping to get as my first bow)
Ah! Thank you, I was looking at that chart earlier, but looking at it again made me realise I'd been reading the key wrong. Turns out I had X7 and 75 mixed up for some reason!

WRITING.TITLE: Target quiver recommendations?
WRITING.TEXT: Now that Christmas has been and gone, I've been thinking of what to do with the money I've been given by family members, and have decided to treat myself to my first quiver. I'm hoping to get a target quiver that isn't going to be too heavy after wearing it all day (I've given myself a bad knee before from carrying too much weight on one side, and I'd rather not do it again) available for a left-handed shooter, and my budget is up to #163;60. I'm still new enough that I'm not sure which brands/models are the most reliable, so any suggestions would be hugely appreciated. I've been looking at the redesigned Avalon Tec One target quiver, so if anyone here can tell me if they're any good, that'd be amazing too!

WRITING.TITLE: Got my first quiver at last (thanks to everyone who gave advice) and had a go at personalising it!

WRITING.TEXT: Apologies for the state of the carpet btw, my chihuahua sheds a lot for such a tiny dog...

It's an Avalon Tec One quiver, bought from Merlin Archery. I painted the beholder on it with Uni Posca paint markers :) (I'm thinking of adding a dragon and/or an orc to it next. I'd love to make it fully D amp;D-themed eventually, maybe painting my bow bag to match when it arrives)
Right? When I first mentioned that I was starting out, two of the players in my group immediately mentioned doing archery too!

I definitely recommend Hadestown and Come From Away (I saw Come From Away in London this last Friday, it was brilliant!) and Blood Brothers if you get the chance. We Will Rock You is ridiculously fun cheese and well worth watching, and Tanz Der Vampires seems to get fairly regular revivals in Germany, so if you need an excuse to visit, there's that :) (if you do ever go, I also recommend watching Starlight Express there in its custom-built arena, and Elisabeth if it's on!)

WRITING.TITLE: Part two of "Project Make My Quiver Look Nerdy" is done!

WRITING.TEXT: I use Uni Posca paint pens to draw the designs onto it :) The two pieces of advice I'd give are to paint several layers, as it absorbs into the fabric quickly and needs to build up (a hairdryer on a low setting can help a lot, as the faster it dries the less it seems to absorb) and spray it with a sealer such as Scotchgard when it's done to protect the design for outdoor shooting.

Yep, but only use Scotchgard once it's finished and completely dry. That's more a protective layer than anything (and optional if you're shooting indoors only, it just gives that extra bit of protection). The most important thing is just adding more layers as each dries.
Happy to help! :D
Sound logic!

I didn't, although I've done similar designs on shoes before now using dressmaker's chalk for the sketch. For this, I stuck with a dragon design that I've drawn enough times to know roughly what it's going to look like (which was still a rather stupid idea, and not one that I'd recommend XD) No tracing, either! It's my own design :)

Ouch, that sounds like a minor nightmare! Dressmaker's chalk is definitely recommended for designs like this. It brushes off very easily, too. (Maybe test it on a patch no one's going to see first, just to make sure it'll work with that particular fabric.)
Stencils, maybe? Stencil effects can look amazing :D

Not that I can think of - bright, blocky colours seem to show up better, so something a bit simpler is best, but other than that it's up to you. I'd just go with whatever you think looks coolest! (And obviously nothing too risqu #233;, the last thing anyone wants is to get in trouble at a tournament or club for their accessories :P)
Ooh, that sounds great!
And now to convince my DM to incorporate that into our homebrew campaign XD
Go for it! :D Grey seems to work well with taking different colours, so if you have a grey quiver too, it should work well!

WRITING.TITLE: When to start using stabilisers?
WRITING.TEXT: I've been shooting recurve weekly for around a couple of months now; I'm still finding my feet, and last Sunday at my club my arm was moving around a lot, so I asked to borrow a stabiliser rod to try out. Immediately my shots got much worse - my arm kept dropping, and I was missing the target a lot before finally settling around 1s and 2s. I thought of leaving it for now, but I do want to get used to using a stabiliser system, particularly as I want to get into competitive target recurve. Is it better to get it out of the way and adapt to using a stabiliser sooner rather than later, or should I leave it until I'm a more confident archer with better form?

Thanks for all the help; I think I might wait a bit longer before trying a stabiliser rod again. I'm admittedly not that strong yet, and as I don't have my form completely down anyway I feel like the extra weight won't exactly do me any good just yet. It may have just been that I was having an off day anyway (which I was) and would be more comfortable with them when things are going more smoothly, but it could also be that I need to build up more strength and work on my form. It's always possible to loan them from my club, so I'll do that again in a few weeks/months and see if I'm any more comfortable making that transition then. :)

I'm looking at getting my first set of arrows next week (either Easton Jazz or Easton Platinum Plus), and as I shoot with a club, I feel like it might be a good idea to distinguish them as mine somehow in case the vane colours aren't enough. I was thinking of writing my initials on the shaft in Sharpie or acrylic paint markers - would this be wise, or would something like paint be enough to affect how well the arrow flies?
That actually sounds like a good idea regardless - a printed arrow wrap with my name is likely to look a lot neater than my own handwriting. :) Thanks for the advice!

I'm starting to think she might be Emma Watson - not known for singing onstage, but does have singing experience from Beauty and the Beast, where she played a Disney Princess. She's been known for her activism and she was famous from a young age! (And while I haven't seen the movie yet, photos of her role in Ballet Shoes show that her character was in an Alice in Wonderland ballet, in a scene with the Queen of Heart's cards - possibly a "Joker in the pack" thing?)
Honestly, the major clue that makes me think it's John Barrowman is the way he shakes his butt. I couldn't think of a more Barrowman-like dance move if I tried! XD
My initial thought (I heard her sing in a clip before seeing the show itself) was Alison Hammond, but now I'm really hoping it is Skin. I love Skunk Anansie!

You can tell my brain's still feeling fuzzy from this head cold of mine when I honestly thought you were going to say "in hope that lost arrows might be picked up by someone hot". Seriously though, that sounds like a great idea for when my club's shoots move outside!

Carbon arrows sadly aren't allowed during the outdoor season in my club, due to the risk of them splintering and injuring anyone who finds the splinters (mostly dog walkers). I guess I could get some for the indoor season, but it's easier to stick with arrows that I can use all year round. :)

It can vary wildly depending on the show - factors such as how difficult the costume is to take off, other tasks they may have to do backstage, waiting for friends and just feeling too tired/not in the mood for being social can all affect this, and there's no guarantee that an actor won't just leave straight away (most will stick around if they're not in a rush, though). The best advice I can offer is to hope for the best while expecting the worst, and to prioritise maybe two or three actors that you're particularly eager to see. Waiting around for hours to get every last autograph isn't fun, so it's often best to pick the ones you're most desperate for and be prepared to call it a day once you've got them even if you're missing other autographs, or once you've gotten confirmation that you won't realistically be getting them.

WRITING.TITLE: D amp;G Magma Green lt;3

WRITING.TEXT: Sadly not, they're made by D amp;G (from their Magma range). I'd love to learn how to make my own someday, though!
Yep, that's where I got them from :) They seem to have a few sets left over, and for that price I couldn't resist!
Unicorn and Fox are still my favourites, but this is making me love Hedgehog even more. XD

The numbers are along the bottom edges rather than the top points. It's admittedly a more confusing and much less popular type of mould, although I quite like the old-school look it tends to give d4s.

So I'm not sure whether to panic or not - my recurve sight arrived (an Avalon Tyro metal sight) and came with two small, thin metal strips that almost look like staples. I wasn't sure what they were (this is my first sight, and it came without any sort of instructions) so I put them aside ready to ask about them at the club. Today it turns out that a family member mistook them for rubbish (I'd kept them in the packaging for safekeeping) and threw them out. So my questions are what were they, were they vital for using the sight and do I need to contact Avalon for replacements?
I keep an arrow puller, string wax, notebook, pen, and my arm guard and shooting glove when I'm not wearing them. And sometimes my headphones for when I want to listen to music during a break. :)

WRITING.TITLE: First time shooting my first ever bow! (Ragim Matrix Evo, 66" and 20lbs. I've named it Bill-bow Baggins.)

WRITING.TEXT: I love it! Nerd-pun bow names are the best bow names :D

It's classed as a beginner model (with a riser carved to encourage you to hold it correctly - holding it properly feels positively dreamy, whereas a death grip just feels downright uncomfortable) so it was surprisingly cheap, too. And it shoots beautifully! Definitely a bow I'd recommend for other newbies/any leftie who fancies a wooden riser.

WRITING.TITLE: Easton Club XT backpack vs. Avalon Classic - which should I get?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm currently using an Avalon Classic soft case for my recurve bow - it's fine, but carrying that much weight on one shoulder gets a bit painful after a while, so I'm thinking of switching to a backpack. My budget isn't great, so I'm thinking of either an Avalon Classic backpack or an Easton Club XT one. I've seen a couple of reviews mentioning the Avalon Classic's fabric splitting along with many more great reviews, and none for the Easton backpack. Does anyone here have experience with either, and can you recommend either one or another in the same price range that's available in the UK? I'd prefer one with enough space for my extra bits and pieces, having to deal with typical women's jean pockets and not really wanting to keep bringing my bag with my bow bag.
I'm wondering if that might be a common Avalon thing... The soft case is decent, but the inserts for accessories seem a bit haphazard.

WRITING.TITLE: Saw this while looking at ebooks. I'd be a bit more willing to forgive the use of a model who doesn't know how to hold a bow if it wasn't for a literal instructional archery book...

WRITING.TEXT: Honestly, I'm not sure if I'm more bothered by his overall form or the fact that he's just asking to string-slap his own nipples off by shooting topless!
Plus he appears to be hooking the string past the first joints of his fingers (hard to see from this angle, but it appears to be the case) so his release is likely to be a bit rough.
Of the muscles, or the ability to go without a top or bra in hot weather and not get in trouble for it? :P Because... yes and yes.
I want one so badly!

Are you in the UK, by any chance? If so, if you're near a Geek Retreat caf #233; there's a good chance that it'll host D amp;D nights. :) If they're anything like my local, they'll likely be very popular and a bit packed, so it's best to call ahead/message them to check whether they still have spaces available if it's a campaign rather than a one-shot.
"Archery: The #1 Beginner's Guide to Impaling Your Own Hand In 3 Easy Steps"

NTA and I'd consider adding two-step authentication to your email account if you can. I had a similar problem with someone using my email to create an Epic Games account a few months ago, and changing my password amp; adding two-step authentication has fixed it. (I changed the password on the Epic Games account too - I have no intent of ever playing Fortnite, but I'm not going to let anyone use my details to play it)

WRITING.TITLE: I doodled my favourite masked singer!

WRITING.TEXT: Thank you! lt;3

WRITING.TITLE: Just finished folding Kade Chan's "Fiery Dragon"!
Got my first indoor handicap today! One step further from being a newbie to a proper archer!

WRITING.TEXT: I'm not very good at explaining it, but there's a link about it here: https://www.archerygb.org/shoot-compete/compete/classification-handicaps/
It's not measured over just one test. They grade you based on at least three rounds to work out your average score and subsequent handicap grade :)

My mum's the same and used to be a light aircraft pilot - she explained that past a certain height, your mind simply can't comprehend how high up you are any more. So being in a high-rise building scares her, but when she flew her plane it just didn't look real enough to be scared of any more.
I'm not sure if they do it in the US, but I'm in the UK :) It's Archery GB's official way to classify skill levels.
My recurve is called Bill. Short for Bill-bow Baggins :) (And those are some gorgeous-looking bows!)
This might be the most adorable arrow mishandling I've ever seen XD

WRITING.TITLE: Aluminium risers that aren't too heavy?
WRITING.TEXT: After a fair bit of saving up, I can finally afford my first aluminium recurve riser amp; limbs (I've been shooting a wooden Ragim Matrix Evo until now). I'm aware that the higher weight will be a huge help in keeping my bow arm steady, but as I have hypermobile joints I have to be careful that it's not too heavy, otherwise my elbow's just going to bend backwards or sideways under the weight - I had a brief hold of another club member's Hoyt bow a while ago to see how an aluminium riser felt and immediately had this issue. Building up my arm muscles should help support my joints a bit more, so I'm working on that, but any suggestions for slightly lighter aluminium risers would be a huge help. (Preferably for an entry-level budget!)

No, it's definitely the weight of the bow itself. I didn't draw the bow that I held to test the feel of it (I was just checking how comfortable the grip felt) and I'm only shooting 20lbs. I'm not having any difficulties with my wooden bow either.
I mean, that head is just asking for scritches...
!SherryPlacement
Honestly, stashing a spare pair in my bag has been a lifesaver in the past. I highly recommend it!

A magnesium one would be fine, come to think of it :) Anything more suited to competitive shooting with greater tuning options than my wooden beginner bow would be perfect if it's light enough! I'll see if my nearest archery shop stocks any of these and/or the other suggested bows, and if so I'll head down in the next week or so to check them out.
I feel like it'd help mine much more if only I could get over target panic!

I'm so, so happy that Jaida did so well in the first episode. When the preview video of the new queens was first released, I watched it with my mum. She took one look at Jaida and immediately went "Oh, yes. She's got to win. She's *beautiful*." I agreed, and I'm so happy to see that we were both proven right so far!

WRITING.TITLE: Do you find that certain sweets make it worse?
WRITING.TEXT: I had my worst bout of trapped air in ages while I was at D amp;D yesterday (one of those where by the end I was nauseous, shivering, in pain from the bloating and could barely function until I was lying down in bed). It's rare that it gets that bad, but I've gotten close a few times at D amp;D, and the one thing I've noticed seems to link all of these cases is that I've bought Mike amp; Ike's jelly beans from the caf #233; we play D amp;D in. Could something in those sweets (perhaps corn syrup, which we don't normally get in the UK) and similar ones cause this? Or maybe even just eating something that chewy?

Can I tie a nocking point without melting the end of the nocking thread? My first new bow string arrived today (the other came with the bow) and I bought some nocking thread with it, then had the realisation that I do not trust my hands to be steady enough not to burn the string itself, or if I manage to avoid that bit then I'm worried about the possibility of the flame reaching the string anyway before I can blow it out. So is this step necessary and should I stop being a wuss, or is there an alternative I can try?
Fellow well-endowed woman here - if you haven't tried it yet, a high-impact sports bra could be a good solution. :) It's been a lifesaver for me.

Just had a go at it - I was still very nervous about pressing the end of it down with my thumb as I've seen in tutorials, so I used the side of a pair of pliers to do that, but I managed it, and it doesn't even look terrible for a first attempt :) Thank you so much for the advice and reassurance!
Sadly no matter how badly I want to burp I still can't, so fizzy drinks are a definite no-go for me unless I'm home, it's already evening and I can sleep through the worst of it XD

When the UK's first patients were flown back home to be quarantined in my hometown. It was still early days when that happened, but just knowing that they were being quarantined so close made it hit home for me.
Positive - in the name of good hygiene, it's only responsible that you get to eat a whole mini dinosaur of tortilla chips by yourself
That fox is one of my favourite designs to fold :D You've done it so well!

WRITING.TITLE: I was saving up for a new metal riser, then my club shut due to the lockdown. Archery GB insurance doesn't cover shooting at home, so say hello to my new backup bow while I wait for the club to reopen!

WRITING.TEXT: Aside from the much thicker/more finger-killing string (even with gloves on!) it's actually not too bad! (Edited to add HAPPY CAKE DAY lt;3)

Sadly my garden's too small to do that, and having a motor control disorder means that even at my most careful, I wouldn't want to shoot without being fully insured just in case (preferably with a coach close by). Better to be safe than sorry in my case!

It comes as part of the membership - I believe it's #163;70 or #163;80 for an annual membership (I pay #163;150 with my club, which covers my Archery GB membership and my club membership amp; venue fees).
Mad Max: Fury Road, and keep Tom Hardy. His dour gruffness as Max while surrounded by characters like Immortan Fozzie and Imperator Piggy would be amazing.

My cat is a mouser, and usually he's great at his job, but there was one time a couple of years ago that I came down one morning to find a mouse just hanging out by the sofa. My cat was sprawled on the sofa, watching this mouse but quite content to do nothing at all about it (this mouse was the cheekiest thing I've ever met, too, and would sit there until I walked over to it, then waddle away just out of reach again). In the end I caught it with a glass bowl and a bit of cake as bait to drop it off in a field the next village over - my cat, helpful mouser that he is, decided that I had everything under control and took a nap for most of this, and the mouse seemed just as happy to sit there eating cake in his temporary home. I'm not sure which of them was lazier!

WRITING.TITLE: Jo Nakashima's capybara, folded by me using 30x30cm tissue foil paper (Guest starring a very sleepy chihuahua in the background)
[FO] With lockdown under effect, I finally had the time to finish this kit!

WRITING.TEXT: The pattern was from the "Cross Stitch: Creations From Nature" kit!
Thanks :D I had a lot of fun stitching this one!

That's the set I've got, and so far it seems to be kind of perfect. :) My back garden is tiny, but it's still just enough to practice form and release, and the bow feels not too dissimilar from my usual recurve.

WRITING.TITLE: It was a challenge and the wings came out slightly worse for wear, but I just about managed to pull off Jo Nakashima's "Devil Dragon v2"!

WRITING.TEXT: That's so cute! I think I need to try this model, it looks great :D

When Hadestown was in London, I waited afterwards to see if I could get any autographs and got to meet Reeve Carney. He was the loveliest and most genuine guy, and he spent ages talking to me and my mum, then stayed what seemed like forever taking the time to talk to the show's fans and making sure everyone who wanted them got photos and autographs. He seemed genuinely touched that so many people wanted to meet him, too. To this day, my mum still refers to him as "that lovely boy we met".

WRITING.TITLE: "Butterfly 2" designed by Rikki Donachie

WRITING.TEXT: I'm not sure where else it's called Wall's, but that's the name here in the UK :)

WRITING.TITLE: [CHAT] Weaving your own aida cloth/evenweave - any suggestions?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm thinking of getting myself a hand loom (never woven before, but I really want to learn) and I'd love to be able to make my own fabric for cross stitch with it. However, I've searched for any sort of tutorials on making things like aida cloth many times with no luck. Has anyone here found anything that might help, or could anyone tell me how I can make my own cross stitch fabric or if it's even possible?

I do - I usually just buy it, but I wanted to give making my own a try mostly to see if I could (and stitching on fabric I've made myself sounds like most satisfying thing!) Plus at the moment it could be useful to be able to make my own when stocks get low. :)
Well, I've ordered a handloom and a load of linen thread, so I'll let you know how I get on :D A simple evenweave should hopefully be doable!
I haven't had any crashes in the past, but for some reason I've had two tonight within maybe 15 minutes of each other. I wonder if they might be experiencing server issues?
Damn it, now I'm sulking that I'm never going to get to see this movie because it sounds amazing XD

It's surprisingly good. :) The bow is 20lbs and 56", and the arrows fit on my regular recurve's serving perfectly, so I've been able to shoot them from my usual bow at home. The target is a little small, but it has holes in the base that allow it to be screwed to a wall for eye-level shooting (it's currently attached to the shed wall). I'd just recommend using duct tape to fix the target to the base if you do that. The bow that comes with it isn't perfect, but it is ambidextrous and fine if you have younger family members who want to shoot. Overall, I'd say it's a good investment for practicing at home. :)
5 - 10m according to the website - my garden is barely big enough for 5m, but it's something :)

WRITING.TITLE: I played completely alone today, right until I came across another Whitecloak the very last stretch. Calamite_974, thank you for making the final ascent with me lt;3
I folded Jo Nakashima's Phoenix and had a go at posing it in the garden

WRITING.TEXT: Yeah, I'd intended to use my time alone to get my final few glyphs (still missing a couple!) but right around the first bit of snow it all started to feel a bit lonely. I was very grateful to find someone else in the end!
I used 30cm tissue foil :) The finished piece has a roughly 20cm wingspan!
Thank you! (And that's probably down to my phone camera, which tends to get a bit weird about close-up proportions XD)
[Immediately thought of this](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zvEe3Y3B2cg)

WRITING.TITLE: Warping frame looms with rotating warp bars for long weaves?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm completely new to weaving, and for my first loom I bought a peg loom with rotating warp bars. I'd love to make a scarf with it, and was wondering if there's a way I could warp it with threads longer than the loom itself to wind up. Could I warp it up for that without getting completely uneven tension?

This is the loom in question: https://www.bergeredefrance.com/wooden-weaving-loom-31-cm-x-45-cm-bergere-de-france.html I've had a go at some practice-projects and it seems good so far - the wingnuts and rotating warp bars are great for taking the finished weave off easily :) I know there must be a way to use it like the scroll frames I embroider on, I just haven't figured it out!

That could actually work - thank you, I'll try that :) I originally thought of cutting individual warp threads of the same length, but then tying the knots exactly the same could be tricky. This could be a much better way, at least until I can move somewhere with the space for a rigid heddle loom! (Dear lord, they look fun...)
"Too Shy" by Kajagoogoo. One of my favourite 80s songs!

WRITING.TITLE: I finally took the plunge and folded this cat designed by Katsuta Kyohei! (40x40cm tissue foil)
How do I preserve tissue foil models?
WRITING.TEXT: For Father's Day this year I'm going to be folding Miyamoto Chuya's Grim Reaper as a gift for my dad (a huge Discworld fan, so I figured he'd enjoy an origami model of Death) and I'm going to be using tissue foil. I'd like to harden and preserve it, but I have no idea how well varnish would work on the foil. Has anyone else here varnished or otherwise preserved tissue foil models, and could anyone here please give advice on how to do this?

I've loved it :) My plan was to visit my nearest shop before the lockdown started to upgrade to a metal riser, but honestly after thinking it over I decided to leave it for now. I'm enjoying the Matrix Evo too much, and it has the bushings for my sight and stabiliser already, so I'm fine for that. The two potential downsides are that it isn't ILF and from what I remember, I think the maximum poundage may not be as high as others (I'll have to double check that) but if you're a beginner or just shoot a lower draw weight as I do, it's a lovely and very smooth bow to shoot. I've gotten a few compliments in my club over how it looks, too!

Are you in the UK/mainland Europe, by any chance? I got mine from Europe Archery, as part of a bundle that included the riser, limbs, arrow rest and a pre-nocked string. Might be worth seeing if you can get one to your specifications that way!

WRITING.TITLE: First attempt at folding Stephan Weber's Bull! (30x30cm tissue foil)
Grim Reaper by Miyamoto Chuya. It's nowhere near as neat as others I've seen, but honestly I'm proud I finished it at all!
Three-headed dragon designed by John Montroll, folded by me from 30x30cm tissue foil (first attempt at this model, after buying my first origami books since I was a kid!)

WRITING.TEXT: I doubt I'm remotely qualified to speculate whether someone is on the spectrum or not, but as an autistic woman her experiences sound a lot like mine growing up, for what it's worth.

WRITING.TITLE: Any advice for transporting a strung recurve?
WRITING.TEXT: My club is finally opening back up for socially distanced shoots, and one of the new rules is that archers must arrive ready to shoot and leave as soon as they're finished. This isn't going to give me much time at all to set up my bow, and either way I'd rather spend as little time as possible there when I'm not actively shooting to minimise any health risks to myself or others. So does anyone here have any recommendations for bags/cases that I could use to transport my 66" recurve strung and as ready to go as is possible, particularly one that I could buy in the UK? (If there's space in there for my sight to be already attached, even better)

WRITING.TITLE: Origami model-in-progress that I almost wanted to leave like this thanks to how satisfyingly symmetrical it was!

WRITING.TEXT: This was the finished piece: https://www.instagram.com/p/CDMNGMUp4-P/?igshid=1tson6rvnlotf (Sadly it got a bit messier as the model progressed!)

WRITING.TITLE: "Dragon v3"designed by Jo Nakashima, folded by me and modelled by my front lawn!

WRITING.TEXT: It was released a few days ago :D It's such a fun one to do, he's really streamlined the neck this time! (And thank you!)

WRITING.TITLE: Help needed deciphering a step in this triceratops by Jerry Harris
WRITING.TEXT: I'm in the middle of folding Jerry Harris' "Triceratops"[(PDF diagram here)](https://www.origami.cz/Pdf/triceratops.pdf) and I am absolutely stuck on steps 50a and 50b. The instructions say to incorporate a rabbit fold, but I'm still completely clueless about how to make it look anything like the resulting fold in step 51. Any advice would be amazingly helpful!

WRITING.TITLE: First attempt at Fiery Dragon v2 by Kade Chan! (35x35cm kraft paper)

WRITING.TEXT: A good site that I've found for all sorts of diagrams, including beginner models, is Origami Resource Center ( https://www.origami-resource-center.com/easy-origami.html ). :) Square origami paper is ideal, but if you don't have any you can make a square out of a sheet of printer paper by following the tutorial below: https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Square-Sheet-of-Paper Best of luck! :D Be sure to show us the end result of whatever you fold!

Ich Will could be a good choice, especially if it's for a German language class :) Not too out there, very catchy and the lyrics are fun to translate without being too difficult (I printed them out recently to try and translate as part of my beginner German practice). Otherwise, I tend to introduce people to them with Engel.

I was 8 and probably watching ReBoot and Disney Channel cartoons, blissfully unaware that maybe 5 - 6 years later I'd be both terrified and thoroughly intrigued by my first German industrial metal music video #128539;
My biggest regret to this day is giving away the complete collection of ReBoot toys I had as a kid! #128517;

Oh, he's such a gorgeous cat! I'm so sorry to hear what's happening, and also glad that he gets to spend all the time he has left in such a comfortable and happy home. It looks like he's utterly spoilt with you, and it's definitely well deserved! lt;3
1986 here! (And turning 34 in 10 days... dear lord I feel old now!)
It's rather nice to know that even German metal stars will still essentially make the same old dad joke of "did someone forget to put a coin in the meter?"
Thank you! I think I'll be taking advantage of some birthday privileges to watch the Madison Square Garden show without my family grumbling at me to turn it off #128514;

WRITING.TITLE: Fanbase nickname?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm a relatively new fan (I quite liked Rammstein as a teenager but never really dove into their stuff until I was quarantined with potential COVID and needed something to pass the time) so apologies if this has already been asked before, but I haven't been able to find anything on it. Anyway, I know some artists' fanbases have nicknames and I was wondering if Rammstein's fans have anything like that. I haven't heard of one, but this seems like the sort of fanbase that would certainly suit having something like that! (If we don't have a nickname yet, I'd like to nominate "Die Haifische" btw...)
Oh god, I was thinking of Deadheads when I thought about this but yeah, that's a good point...
That's fair. Admittedly it's a fandom I'm still learning about (may have also forgotten that nicknames are more of a pop thing nowadays!)

When I was a kid we had a lurcher, and my kid self thought it was a great idea to teach him to leap over the kitchen gate like this. I didn't entirely get why my parents were so against the idea once they found out what I'd taught him...
Honestly, my first thought was "Yep, lockdown hair got all of us" XD

I'd start with either the Paris version of Du Hast or the Madison Square Garden version of Engel, but other than that the choice is pretty much endless :) A good one for showcasing the sheer spectacle of the pyrotechnics is this video of Sonne, btw: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z3rxV9-DLgA

I've also been doing it for a few weeks now! #128512; (I had an inconclusive COVID test along with symptoms and had to stay quarantined; to keep myself entertained I both got into Rammstein and then started trying to learn German.)Viel Gl #252;ck! I hope yours is going really well!
33 here and this is the first I've heard of that! Weirdly, I have the soapy-taste gene, but I actually really like coriander/cilantro...
Something instantaneous and painless, and I'd be playing/watching something in VR at the time so I'd never even see it coming.

I've only had GA once, but the worst part was just my anxiety (and needle phobia) beforehand. Once I was out, I didn't notice a thing until I woke up after the surgery and proceeded to insist I could walk back to the ward myself (I couldn't)

Thank goodness I didn't freak out afterwards (I had an oophorectomy, so other than my drugged-up self wondering if I could pull my IV line out I was okay on that front) but as a 15 year old who insisted on being as independent as possible I must have been a minor nightmare for the nurses #128517;

I find that thinking about what I'm going to do afterwards helps. That and reminding yourself that the fear of it is much greater than the actual event, which hurts significantly less than something like bumping your elbow on something or accidentally scratching yourself. And find something else to look at; you can ask the anaesthetist to hide anything they'll be using out of sight, and look at a wall or shut your eyes while talking to them about something unrelated. :) And remember that you can do this!
Be sure to post here afterwards to let us know how it went, too :) (browsing on Reddit on your phone once you've gotten out of surgery could even be a nice thing to plan for as a distraction!)
Yeah, they're not fun, but honestly you don't really notice it. You'll be out cold when they put it in, and you won't feel it once it's there as long as you leave it alone.

She's gorgeous, and it looks like you're doing great with her already! :D Apologies if you've already heard these, but if not then they might be useful to know as a first-time dog owner: giving her worn items of your clothes to snuggle up with will help her get used to your scent faster (maybe not socks for the simple reason that many dogs find them irresistible to play with and can steal them with ninja-like sneaking skills if left unattended) and if you practice "sit" with her often enough and make it a fun trick for her, it can be a great way to stop your dog in her tracks if she's gotten out/is trying to jump up to reach something she shouldn't.
Thank you! I was trying to remember where I knew her name from!
Our chihuahua stashes them under his pile of toys! I generally find a fair few whenever I dig through that pile while doing the laundry.

I'm ashamed to say I've done this, just once when I was in school. I went to the bathrooms, did my business, flushed and watched in horror as the toilet filled up almost to the point spilling over, presumably clogged, and nothing budged. I was too embarrassed and horrified to think of anything else to do about it (plus I was an already-bullied kid and knew that the other pupils would be merciless if they knew what I'd done) so I just washed my hands and sprinted out of there before anyone else could see or pin the evidence on me. I can only hope the cleaner who found it afterwards forgave me for it.

WRITING.TITLE: Got "Advanced Origami" by Michael G. LaFosse and Richard L. Alexander for my birthday and folded this goldfish from it!

WRITING.TEXT: I'll give it a go :D Some of these are so difficult (I attempted the second bat, and I think I'm going to need to look up a tutorial on how to get the wings right) but I do like a challenge!

I think it was the brown bat. I haven't even gotten that far yet, the one diagram filled with endless pre-creases killed me a bit #128517; I'll save that one until I've had a decent amount of sleep! (Which couldn't be said the first time I tried it)
Difficult choice, but I'd say these at the moment: 1. Ich Tu Dir Weh 2. Rammlied 3. Engel 4. Mein Teil 5. Sonne

WRITING.TITLE: Of all the birthday cards I got this morning, I particularly love this one from my parents!
